body_text.text: Aquatic chemical ecology reveales the complexity of the chemical language spoken under water, but also results in novel and bioactive molecules from marine and freshwater organisms. At the basis of aquatic food webs, photosynthetic algae are living under the constant pressure from grazers and competitors. To thrive, algae can rely on small diffusible molecules to organize the colonization of substratum, find food, and fight against herbivores and pathogens. Algae also use pheromones to improve mating success and increase their population. The chemical cues mediating the biotic interactions of algae are infochemicals and their nature and ecological function is the main subject of algal chemical ecology. The diversity of algal chemicals is astounding and their bioactive properties nowadays serve in many biotechnological applications. [1] [2] [3] [4] The first book on algal chemical ecology was published in 2008 and shed light on the importance of algae and their molecules. 5 Since then, many more algal infochemicals have been characterized and their ecological function has been unraveled. Some recent reviews focused on specific topics such as the chemical mediators of macroalgae-bacteria interaction, 6 algal mating, 7 and the chemical ecology of specific groups, for example marine planktonic microalgae. 8, 9 In the present article, we propose an updated inventory of the chemical ecology of algae organized per type of interaction, illustrated with hallmark examples from the last decade ( Fig. 1 ). This work includes the intraspecific interactions (within one species) with algal sex pheromones that coordinate mating (Section 2), the interspecific interactions (between species) such as symbiosis (ranging from mutualism to parasitism) (Section 3), allelopathy (Section 4), grazing defense (Section 5), and algal biofilm interactions (Section 6). The algae detailed in this article belong to several evolutionary supergroups, encompassing the Chlorophytes, Rhodophytes and Glaucophytes (Archaeplastida), Chlorarachniophytes (Rhizaria/Excavates), Cryptophytes, Dinophytes, and Haptophytes. The major lineage Stramenopiles from the Chromista/Alveolata kingdom includes the diatoms (Bacillariophyceae), the brown algae (Phaeophyceae), and the golden algae (Chrysophyceae). More information on the phylogeny and biology of algae is available in the recent book The Algae World. 10 We excluded prokaryotic algae, cyanobacteria, and lichenic associations, as two recent books thoroughly described their ecology. 11, 12 Algae presented here are ubiquitous in aquatic habitats, inhabiting ecosystems, from ocean floors (benthos) to pelagic and intertidal, lakes, streams, and other flow motion-driven systems. Living mainly submerged under water, algae shape their environment not only by their physical presence, but also exude metabolites that accumulate in a diffusion-limited area around the producing cells, hence forming the phycosphere. 13 Algae exhibit a phenotype, which is defined as the complete set of observable morphological, developmental, behavioral, biochemical, and physiological properties. Eukaryotic algae can be free-living as planktonic single cells in pelagic ecosystems and can encounter other species that can negatively or positively impact them. Micro-and macroalgae also live on inorganic substrata (e.g., sediment, rocks, sand) or in symbiosis with micro-or macroorganisms including sponges, ciliates, coral polyps, mammals, or other algae. Macroalgae (seaweeds) can harbor diverse symbiotic microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and microalgae, which can live on the algal surface (epiphytes) or within the host tissues (endophytes). The algae and their associated microbiota can answer to a stressor as a whole entity, termed the algal holobiont, or in separate responses. 6 In fact, micro-and macroalgae often depend upon the associated microbial community to grow or withstand stressors and harsh environmental conditions. Some associated microbiota modulates algal host behavior and physiology or can determine the morphological development as in the case of green algae Ulva sp. 14, 15 The interactions between algae and microorganisms, ranging from parasitism to mutualism, and from obligate to conditional (facultative) associations, often result in extensive variation of the holobiont phenotype, on which selection and evolution can act. These interactions rely upon chemical mediators and some of the most striking and recently investigated examples are depicted in the following sections.

Intraspecific signaling is mediated by chemical cues that are termed pheromones. In algae, life cycle transitions are often synchronized by pheromones, but also mate finding processes can occur in the gradient of attraction pheromones. Algae have different sexual strategies, with life cycles characterized by the transition from haploid to diploid phases, which are mediated by highly diverse molecules that range from small nonpolar hydrocarbons to high-molecular weight polar glycoproteins. We kindly direct the readers to recent reviews that cover the structures of sex pheromones in green algae, diatoms, and brown algae. 7, 16 In this section, we selectively focus on the recent investigations that addressed pheromone-mediated mechanisms involved in diatom sexual reproduction.

Microalgae are often asexual organisms and a population of the same species can be genetically homogeneous or heterogeneous. 17, 18 Hence the consensual definition of species cannot be applied to all unicellular algae as conspecific microalgae can share low degrees of genetic identity. These issues were addressed in the excellent review by Venuelo et al. 17 Unicellular and colonial microalgae often share similar process for their sexual reproduction. Two specialized, sexually compatible cell types (the haploid gametes) are produced by meiosis or by activation of a sexual program in reproducing cells. In the case of diatoms, asexual reproduction occurs by successive mitotic events often resulting in a mean size reduction of the cells within the population. 7 This is Fig. 1 Algal chemical interactions in aquatic ecosystems. The intra-and interspecific interactions that are described in this article are illustrated, e.g. allelopathy to other organisms, susceptibility to parasites, capacity to deter grazing and ability to mate and reproduce. The zone where released chemicals are effective is depicted with clouds (phycosphere) and the interaction types are highlighted with double-pointed arrows. Algal biofilm interactions of complex benthic communities are also considered within this framework, including mating and defense against grazers/competitors. due to the constriction of the biomineralized cell wall. New cell wall formation occurs within the constraints of the parent cell and, as a consequence, the daughter cells are reduced in size. Cells eventually reach the sexual size threshold, upon which differentiation in two different mating types (MT+, MT −) is observed. In the benthic model diatom Seminavis robusta, for example, these mating types start secreting the sex-inducing pheromones (SIP), SIP+ and SIP−, respectively (Fig. 2) . 19 Under the influence of the SIP, one mating type secretes an attraction pheromone while the other type probably expresses a pheromone receptor. The first sex attraction pheromone was identified in 2013 from S. robusta by using an untargeted metabolomics approach. 20 The exudates (exometabolome) of the mating type that attracts its conspecific opposite sex by means of a pheromone were profiled. Samples collected from cultures that were either induced by application of the SIP or from uninduced controls were compared. A proline-derived diketopiperazine was only present in the samples from the SIP-induced cells that also attracted the opposite sex (Fig. 2) . After synthesis of the pheromone candidate, the attraction of mating type (MT −) by diproline was demonstrated in assays using solidphase extraction beads that were loaded with defined amounts of the compound. The attraction and the movement pattern of the mating partner were monitored using video documentation. The statistical modeling confirmed a combined chemotactic and chemokinetic response of the motile cells toward the pheromone source. 21 Despite the fact that S. robusta only releases (S,S)diproline, also (R,R)-diproline displayed similar attraction activity. 19, 22 This motivated further structure-activity relationship studies on the pheromone reception using a synthetic library of diproline-derived products. 22 All stereoisomers of diproline and also the structurally related pipecolic acid-derived diketopiperazine triggered an attraction response. But, diketopiperazines derived from acyclic amino acids and compounds where the heterocycles were functionalized with polar substituents were not active. The general diketopiperazine motive is invariant, but the stereochemistry and ring size are recognized with a certain promiscuity. The sex-inducing pheromone (SIP +) was purified from the mating type (MT+) and induced the cell cycle arrest of (MT −) cells. 19 SIP+ is produced in very small amounts by the sexually active cells but metabolomics supported by high-resolution mass spectrometry with fragmentation analysis identified this compound as a sulfated metabolite with a pseudomolecular ion of m/z 842. These findings indicate that, even within a single diatom species, chemically distinct metabolites that are most likely derived from different metabolic pathways are mediating sexual induction and mate finding. Similarly to other known algal attraction pheromones, diproline acts in the direct vicinity of the calling cell, while SIP-mediated synchronization is most likely a long-range process. This illustrates the existence of sophisticated mechanisms to increase chances of mate finding, along with a mutual communication between both mating types of the diatom Seminavis robusta. Observations indicate that other diatoms have elaborate pheromone systems as well, but the structures of the receptors and the pheromones have yet to be characterized.

If diatoms are challenged by giving them the choice between nutrient sources and mate pheromones, the unicellular organisms can even decide depending on their respective need, and which stimulus they select. 23 Seminavis robusta of different size were either grown as control or starved in medium that was depleted in dissolved silicate (dSi), an essential diatom nutrient. Sex-induced and nutrient depleted cells were then subjected to attraction assays, exposing the diatoms to dSi or diproline-loaded beads. The attraction to either of the beads was recorded by video and the cell-tracking data were analyzed. While large cells only search for dSi when starved and are not responsive for pheromones, smaller cells move to the pheromone or dSi source depending of their need. Medium-sized cells search for pheromones when induced with SIP and supplemented with dSi. Small cells, in contrast, abandon all regulative principles and prioritize for the attraction pheromone independent of induction or degree of starvation. The need for sexual reproduction apparently triggers an unconditional pheromone search. This study certainly demonstrated that unicellular algae can alter their searching behavior in a context-dependent manner to maximize procreation. The elucidated pheromones provide also a tool for the systematic investigation of trans-kingdom interactions in biofilms. By following the reproductive success and pheromone concentration in S. robusta cultures it became evident that certain bacteria, including Maribacter sp. and Marinobacter sp., can negatively affect diatom reproduction by targeted degradation of the sex pheromones of the algae. 24 In the microalgal world, two other models were proposed and much progress has been made toward the understanding of the sexual reproduction process. The green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii and the Charophycean alga from the genus Closterium which is genetically more related to land plants are under intensive investigation. We kindly refer the readers to the recent and comprehensive reviews from Tsuchikane and Sekimoto. 16, 25 The applications of new genetic methods such as the CRISPR/Cas9based knockout will certainly give more insights into the molecular mechanisms of sex mating in algae.

Micro-and macroalgae are characterized by diverse morphologies, are ubiquitous around the globe, and they are involved in many different mutualistic interactions and selected recent highlights in mutualism research are illustrated in the following. We do not cover methods associated with assessing coral-algal symbioses, specifically with Symbiodinium sp. but rather direct the interested reader to the following reviews [27] [28] [29] for a thorough discussion of the topic.

Microalgae and bacteria are well-suited to associate. Microalgae, as the major aquatic primary producers, belong to the basis of the aquatic food webs and provide organic resources to bacteria and higher consumers. 30, 31 The advances in culturing methodologies along with progress in analytical chemistry shed light on how these bacteria and algae interact. 32 Most algae require auxotropic uptake of vitamin B , 33 a water-soluble vitamin produced only by prokaryotes. 34 This requirement for bacterial metabolites is likely at the beginning of a mutualistic interaction, one that Kazamia and colleagues investigated in the green alga Lobomonas rostrate. 35 The first experiment was the cocultivation of L. rostrata with various bacterial species on autotrophic medium that did not contain a carbon source for the bacteria nor vitamin B 12 for the algae. Some of these bacteria, such as Mesorhizobium loti, are known to contain the genes required to synthesize vitamin B 12 . Monocultures of L. rostrata and M. loti did not grow on the autotrophic medium but were able to grow in coculture or when supplemented with carbon (in the form of glycerol) and vitamin B 12 , suggesting an interdependence of the two species. To define the dependence, cocultures of the bacteria and algae were inoculated with different ratios of bacterial and algal cells and in all tested ratios, within 5-7 days, the coculture equilibrated to a ratio between 1:10 and 1:30 L. rostrata to M. loti cells. This suggested a level of regulation which was further investigated by adding exogenous vitamin or glycerol to disrupt the ratio of algal to bacterial cells. Disruption in favor of the bacterial cells upon addition of glycerol and in favor of the algal cells upon addition of vitamin B 12 supported the hypothesis that the mutualism was based upon reciprocal transfer of nutrients. Kazamia and colleagues went on to further prove that the transfer of nutrients, both algal and bacterial-derived, was occurring via diffusion of compounds instead of due to physical contact. 36 Therefore bacterial cells were maintained inside a dialysis tube that was administered to L. rostrata. The tube prevented physical contact of the cells but allowed diffusion of compounds. After prolonged incubation a halo of algal cells had formed around the dialysis tube, likely resulting from bacterial released vitamin. The cell lysis-based release of compounds alone was insufficient to mediate the mutualistic relationship. This elegant experimental design, including identifying the partners of the interaction, describing their dependence, and defining the cost/benefits for each partner, could enable further investigation of algal-bacterial interactions.

A second well-described algal-bacterial mutualism involves the bacterial-promoted assimilation of iron in the alga Scrippsiella trochoidea. 36 Amin and coworkers detailed the mutualistic release of vibrioferrin-iron chelates from Marinobacter sp. in exchange for algal-derived organic molecules. Vibrioferrin is known to be a relatively weak chelating agent as it contains only five chelating functionalities instead of the six that are common in most marine siderophores. 37 As two of the five chelating moieties were a-hydroxy acids, the authors hypothesized that vibrioferrin would be more photolabile, leading to the faster reduction of Fe(III) to Fe(II). Fe(II) can then undergo dissociation from the siderophore and upon subsequent reoxidation to inorganic ferric hydrolysis species, be readily utilized by algal cells. 38, 39 Amin and coworkers first investigated the specific rate of photolysis of vibrioferrin, petrobactin, and marinobactin, all previously described marine siderophores, and found that vibrioferrin demonstrated a 10-fold higher rate of photolysis than other siderophores as predicted. Using 55 Fe, they were then able to show that axenic cultures S. trochoidea supplemented with vibrioferrin-iron chelates and sunlight, had significantly higher rates of iron uptake when compared to the same additives in the dark, further supporting the involvement of photolability of the vibrioferrin-iron complex in iron exchange. Similar results were seen when the vibrioferrin-iron complex was photolyzed separately and then added to axenic cultures of S. trochoidea in the dark. The high degree of photolability of vibrioferrin is likely harmful for the producing bacterium, suggesting that the associated algae must transfer some beneficial compounds to the bacteria for the relationship to persist. In accordance, growth in cocultures of Marinobacter spp. with S. trochoidea was enhanced compared to Marinobacter spp. controls. Additional to Amin's work, several studies show that Marinobacter species can utilize organic compounds released by marine algae 40, 41 and that the Marinobacter genome contains a range of genes for the transport and metabolism of these compounds. 42 While the specific compounds transmitted between S. trochoidea and Marinobacter spp. are still unknown, the mutualistic relationship is strongly supported.

Surfaces of macroalgae are commonly colonized by bacterial biofilms, epiphytes, and marine invertebrates. Many of these associations are prolonged over the entire lifespan of the algae and provide a setting for close metabolic and physical interactions. The nature of the association determines the fitness of both the colonizer and the algae. In one study, 32% of all bacteria isolated from algae were able to metabolize macroalgae-derived polysaccharides, suggesting the existence of potentially mutualistic relationships. 43 One of the most-studied mutualistic associations occurs between the green alga Ulva spp. and its associated bacteria. [44] [45] [46] Ulva sp. requires two cooccurring bacteria to develop properly: Cytophaga sp. promotes rhizoid formation while Roseobacter sp. promotes proper cell division and thallus formation in Ulva sp. (Fig. 3 ). 14 Exuded compounds from the associated bacteria promote proper morphogenesis of Ulva sp. Bioassay-guided fractionation revealed that the bacteria-derived compound thallusin (1) (Fig. 4) is the inducing thallus formation. 47 Spoerner and colleagues showed via inverted light microscopy of petri dishes containing axenic and nonaxenic cultures of Ulva sp. that Roseobacter sp. are attracted to the developing algae, suggesting a specific assemblage of bacteria common to Ulva sp. 44 Due to this preferred association, it was hypothesized that co-occurring bacteria also benefit from the association. In fact, glycerol is excreted by Ulva sp. and Roseobacter sp. isolated from this alga can grow on a medium with glycerol as carbon source. Roseobacter sp. benefits from algal-derived compounds in a mutualistic association. 48

Coralline, or crustose coralline algae, which are red algae exhibiting calcified thalli unlike other algae, can form unique relationships with higher organisms. All species known, with the exception of Pneophyllum cetinaensis, 49 are marine and are rarely chemically defended, requiring close associations with herbivores to clean their surfaces of biofoulers. 50, 51 For example, the coralline alga Neogoniolithon strictum forms a mutualistic relationship with the crab, Mithrax sculptus, in which the crab gains refuge from predators and the alga is cleaned of its epiphytes. 52 Algae without crabs were found to support nine times the growth of epiphytes versus algae hosting crabs after only days. However, this association also requires that the herbivorous crabs consume other macroalgae, some chemically defended, that tend to co-occur with the coralline algae. 52 In another association, the chiton Choneplax lata stimulates meristematic growth of the coralline alga Poolithon pachydermum, upon its consumption. 53 The mechanism of growth stimulation and the causative association, which appears to be mutualistic, is not well understood on a metabolic level. While some have hypothesized that coralline algae attract beneficial associations through chemical mediators, no evidence to support the hypothesis yet exists. We propose that both a thorough understanding of the metabolism of coralline algae and of the interactions with co-occurring species is required before investigations into chemically mediated symbiosis is addressed.

Parasites of algae include bacteria, viruses, fungi, chytrids, or even other algae species living at the host's expense as epibionts on the cell surface, or as endobionts in the tissue or cell of the algae. Parasites rely on their host to accomplish their lifecycle and can thus be distinguished from pathogens that are opportunistic organisms. 54 In this section we describe some important concepts on parasitism in the algal world that are often scattered in previous works, as well as selected breakthroughs studies of the last decade that involved algae-parasite interactions.

Many fungus-like microorganisms, for example, oomycetes, perkinsozoans, labyrinthulids, cryptomycota, and aphelids, are able to infect both unicellular microalgae 55 and seaweeds. 56, 57 Signaling is involved in host finding as algal exudates attract free-living forms of parasites, 58, 59 yet the structural identity of the involved factors remains mostly unknown. The zwitterionic dimethylsulfoniopropionate, a well-known osmoregulator produced by algae and bacteria alike, is one of the few identified factors with a defined role in mutualistic interactions; it can attract many aquatic organisms, including potential parasites of algae. 60 Parasitic chytrids and oomycetes are structurally adapted to their parasitic lifestyle and depend upon transfer into the host to accomplish sexual reproduction. 54 The life cycle of these parasitic organisms consists of two stages: a free-living infective form (the motile spore) that can swim and infect new algae, and a host-associated form (the trophont) that feeds upon the algal cell and produces, in a later infection stage, a reproductive cell (the sporocyst) ( Fig. 5 ). 61 The parasite can induce a reduction of the host fitness, or, if it is effectively killing the alga it is referred as a parasitoid. 62 Virulence factors are all effectors that enable the parasite to establish itself in the host and enhance its potential to cause disease. 63 These effectors can mediate toxicity, attachment, and protection against the host defense and contribute to the overall pathogenicity of the parasite. One important other factor influencing the infection rate is the host susceptibility and this was proven in different models of algae-parasites interactions. [64] [65] [66] In the field, parasites and algae do not coexist in isolation, but in multispecies systems that can be affected by other biotic interactions, such as grazing. Intriguingly, microalgae infected by parasites are preferred by microzooplankton, hence parasites also indirectly modulate aquatic food webs. 67 This connection between parasitism and grazing has also been shown in field studies. 68 But also grazing on the free-living parasites can significantly decrease parasitic infection in dinoflagellate populations of Akashiwo sanguinea. 69 Investigations of the community with numerical simulations and modeling showed that high nutrient concentrations might promote algal growth and stimulate bloom control by the parasites. 70 Parasites can differ in specificity; some are specialists with a host range limited to one species, while others are generalists and able to infect a wide variety of algal species. 63 A long history of coevolution and intimate coexistence reflects the specificity of the parasite, which can shift from generalist to specialist on an evolutionary timescale. 71 Conversely, parasites must also overcome the algal resistance through virulence factors to optimize the host exploitation and the infection transmission. This antagonistic coevolution results in a continuous arms race of defense and counter-defense, defined as the "Red Queen" hypothesis. 72 This evolutionary hypothesis proposes that organisms must constantly adapt and evolve to survive against opposing coevolving organisms, and is well-supported for hosts and parasites which coevolve by favoring sexual reproduction in one or both partners. Sex generates rare genotypes by meiotic recombination, which can be selectively favored if the parasite adapted to the most common host genotypes. This connection served to explain the constant extinction rates observed in the paleontological records for microalgae and parasites. 71, 73, 74
body_text.section: Concepts and ecological relevance of algal parasitism

body_text.text: In recent years, a major breakthrough has been accomplished by establishing model pathosystems in the lab as well as by achieving cryopreservation to control and maintain parasites of algae over time. 75, 76 To maintain parasites in culture, infected cells are isolated from field samples, then diluted and reisolated several times sequentially by single-cell micromanipulation (one infected algal cell is physically isolated using glass micropipettes under a microscope and placed again into healthy host cultures). The infection is then maintained in cultures by successive inoculation of a new host population using few infected cells or the mobile infective spores of the parasites. Both algae and parasites can thus be cocultivated in laboratory controlled cultures. This first step has been manually completed for few selected systems, but the development of automatized cell sorting methods will likely lead to the establishment of novel pathosystems in the future. However, the isolation of the parasite is often compromised by short infection cycles and synchronization causes difficulties since a susceptible host has to be provided at the right time.
body_text.section: Recent breakthroughs in algae-parasite interaction research

body_text.text: For microalgae, the most ground-breaking results involved the harmful dinoflagellates Alexandrium spp. and the marine prymnesiophyte Emiliania huxleyi as hosts. The genus Alexandrium is globally distributed and is considered as one of the most harmful group of algae, responsible of many outbreaks of food poisoning in humans referred as Paralytic Shellfish Poisoning. 77 This is due to the algal production of saxitoxin that accumulates in the food chain and is neurotoxic to humans. 78 A. minutum forms periodical blooms in coastal waters when nutrient pulses from rivers, flooding urban areas and agricultural watersheds, induce temporary eutrophication conditions. During these events, highly virulent parasites have the ability to control toxic harmful algal blooms (HABs), as proven by field observations and model predictions. 79, 80 For instance, many parasites from the genus Parvilucifera spp., marine alveolates from the phylum Perkinsozoa, accounted for 5-18% of the total observed A. minutum mortality in the field from 2009 to 2013. 81 Although the molecular mechanism of the infection remains unclear, the infochemical which triggers the maturation and release of the infectious parasite has been identified as dimethyl sulfide. 82 This volatile compound is produced by the algae in a cell-density dependent manner and possesses multiple roles in the biogeochemistry of the marine sulfur cycle as well as in biotic interactions of algae. 83 Besides the pathosystem Parvilucifera/Alexandrium, infections by viruses and bacteria have been studied in great detail during the blooms of the marine phytoplankton E. huxleyi. 84 This microalga is abundant in oceanic euphotic zones and can affect the global sulfur cycle by producing large amounts of dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP) and its volatile metabolic product dimethyl sulfide. During E. huxleyi blooms, the virus EhV can be recruited and induces lysis of the algal population. The infection can be transmitted over long distances by aerosols 85 or possibly even by virus transfer via zooplankton, 86 thus enhancing its propagation from algal bloom to another.
body_text.section: Recent breakthroughs in algae-parasite interaction research

body_text.text: The infection rewires the algal metabolism and induces sphingolipid biosynthetic genes, as shown by comparative transcriptomics and metabolomics analysis. 87 A strong induction of specific glycosphingolipids results from the viral challenge and also the regulation of some terpenes and sterols modulate the infection process. To test the importance of steroids, several inhibitors were applied to infected cultures and the viral productivity was assessed with cell enumeration. Cerivastatin, a specific inhibitor of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA reductase in the mevalonate-isoprenoid pathway leading to steroids, significantly reduced the viral amount, without being toxic to algal cells. Since virus capsids contain algal steroids, it was concluded that reduction of steroid biosynthesis by the host inhibits viral propagation. Viral and algal gene expression monitored in the field during a phytoplankton bloom suggested that the induction of sphingolipids was also occurring under natural conditions. 88 In accordance with the Red Queen hypothesis, the viral infection induced sexual reproduction and meiosis in the host populations, resulting in the increase and subsistence of resistant haploid cells. The difference in ploidy led to two morphotypes in the population, one resistant and one susceptible, that were identified with microscopy techniques. 89 Intriguingly, the class of lipids was involved in the signaling in the host pathogen interaction. Small extracellular vesicles are indeed produced during the infection and induced a faster viral infection rate when internalized by the algal host E. huxleyi. 90, 91 This mode of communication via vesicles was only recently discovered in aquatic ecosystems and may be more universally present in planktonic systems. In the discussed example it might function to lengthen the lifespan of the EhV virus or to ease the long-distance transmission of small labile and liposoluble infochemicals.
body_text.section: Recent breakthroughs in algae-parasite interaction research

body_text.text: The algicidal bacteria from the genus Roseobacter and Sulfitobacter are also involved in the demise of E. huxleyi blooms, demonstrating that not only one single key-player could be involved in the algal bloom termination. 92 The central role of DMSP was demonstrated in this pathosystem as algal strains exuding higher amounts of this metabolite were more susceptible to the bacterial infection. 92 The exogenous application of DMSP in the cultures of the host led to an increase of the bacterial virulence as well as the induction of the host susceptibility. This study presented a new role for DMSP as mediator of the virulence in microalgaeparasite interactions. Conversely, some other bacteria from the same Roseobacter clade of a-Proteobacteria usually promote the growth of its host E. huxleyi by synthesizing and secreting antibiotics and growth stimulants (2, 3) ( Fig. 6 ). Intriguingly, these bacteria could also switch to an opportunistic behavior by producing potent and selective roseobacticide (3) that lyses the host. 93 The lytic products were released in response to p-coumaric acid (4), an algal lignin breakdown product associated to the aging algae. The case of Roseobacter was the first proof that associated symbionts could shift from a mutualistic to pathogenic lifestyle according to the physiological status of its algae host.
body_text.section: Recent breakthroughs in algae-parasite interaction research

body_text.text: A culture-dependent approach led to the isolation of the microbial community of fungal endophytes associated with the inner tissues of several brown macroalgae, including kelp species from the genus Laminaria that are economically important. 94 To test the hypothesis that these fungi were mutualistic, activity of their metabolome was assessed against a broad range of major protistan pathogens of algae. The functional bioassay consisted in the dual cultivation of the infected brown alga Ectocarpus siliculosus with a healthy filament of the same alga retained in a nylon-mesh strainer, incubating in a medium supplemented with fungal extracts. The ability to reduce the infection in Ectocarpus was quantified by microscopy and RT-PCR. The active metabolites were further characterized with a conventional natural product chemistry approach, yielding several polyketides from the pyrenocines family, pyrenocines A (6), B 7, and pyrenochaetic acid C (8) , which inhibit the infection at submicromolar concentration (Fig. 7) . The compounds efficiently inhibited the infection by protistan parasites of algae, including the two most devastating pathogens of seaweeds, the oomycetes Olpidiopsis pyropia and Pythium porphyrae. The production of these molecules in the host has yet to be characterized, but this study gave further proof that algal microbiota and their chemicals may drive the infection success of parasites and pathogenic microbes in the phycosphere. These findings were empowered by the use of a cultivable algae-parasite system, showing the importance of establishing robust pathosystems for mechanistic investigations. Several other models were established for microalgal/pathogen interactions, accounting for economically exploited freshwater green algae Haematococcus pluvialis and Graesiella sp., infected by the fungus Paraphysoderma 95 and chytrid Rhizophydium scenedesmi, 96 respectively. Other pathosystems include the parasitic oomycetes Lagenisma coscinodisci, Miracula helgolandica, and Olpidiopsis drebesii which infect bloom-forming marine diatoms. 97, 98 These new systems will certainly yield more information on the molecular mechanism of infection in microalgae-parasite interactions, providing that cultures can be scaled up and that more sensitive analytics are employed to finely tune in the communication of these unicellular organisms. Single-cell omics may render possible a monitoring of cross-domain interactions at the intracellular scale, allowing the characterization the individual algal cellular response. While, for example, hormones that are responsible for the mediation of resistance in higher plants are well understood, such cellular effectors are not known in algae. Monitoring the cellular response might provide a direct access to such regulatory metabolites. [99] [100] [101]
body_text.section: Recent breakthroughs in algae-parasite interaction research

body_text.text: The microbial loop allows commensalism between eukaryotic algae and aerobic prokaryotic heterotrophs. In the microbial world, commensalism is mostly related to nutrition, for example, the association between two species in which the host is not affected and the symbiont benefits, which is likely the most difficult symbiotic relationship to observe in the algal world. The ability to investigate such claims, most importantly the "neutral effect" on the host, is difficult to observe due to an inability to maintain the interacting organisms in captivity, and a general lack of understanding of host physiology and metabolism. Without a thorough understanding of the individual partners involved in the commensalistic interaction, the chemicals responsible for mediating the interaction, the metabolic changes as consequences of the interaction, and the chemical understanding of the relationship cannot be properly assessed. A major exception to this is the so-called microbial loop, or the trophic pathway in which aerobic prokaryotic heterotrophs recycle dissolved organic carbon released by eukaryotic algae. As the focus of this article is on the algal symbionts, we direct the interested reader to several reviews detailing the microbial loop and benefits of the prokaryotic symbionts. 30, 102, 103 4 Allelopathy

Competition is a common aspect of algal life, including competing for nutrients, light or space. Among all groups of algae, the process of exuding compounds that affect competitor fitness, i.e. allelopathy, is a common strategy for interspecies competition. While most reports are on the negative effects of allelopathy on competitor growth, 104, 105 recent research has shed light on how some competitors can utilize exuded compounds to enhance their growth. 106, 107 Negative allelopathy is believed to be an "intentional" consequence of competition (e.g. a weapon against competitors) while positive allelopathy is believed to be an "opportunistic" consequence of competition (one man's trash is another man's treasure). In both cases, similar methodologies exist for investigating allelopathy. Because of the complex nature of algal communities in benthic biofilms, these interactions will be discussed in details in Section 6.

The ease of laboratory-based microalgal cultivation has led to a significant number of studies investigating microalgal allelopathy. Large culture collections such as the National Center for Marine Algae and Microbiota (https://ncma.bigelow.org/), the Roscoff plankton collection (http://roscoff-culture-collection.org/), the Culture Collection of Algae and Protozoa, 108 and the UTEX culture collection 109 (among many others) give researchers world-wide access to many phytoplankton species that stand representative for the diversity in the oceans but comprise only a limited number of species that emerge as model organisms. This availability has led to a disturbing trend in plankton allelopathy research: an overabundance of studies focusing on these curated cultures without a field component. 8, 110 As will become clear in the following examples, laboratory-based investigations are numerous, with sophisticated culturing techniques for addressing multispecies interactions, yet the incorporation of fresh samples and bloom samples are relatively sparse.

The first step in any allelopathy investigation is to prove that the causative agent responsible for an observed alteration of competitor fitness is chemically derived. Historically, this was done by subjecting competitor algae to extracts, or cell-free filtrates of conditioned seawater and comparing the growth of the competitor algae to that of a control (competitor algae not subjected to allelopathic extracts). Prince and colleagues generated extracellular extracts of the harmful algal bloom-forming dinoflagellate Karenia brevis by incubating K. brevis cultures with a mixture of adsorbent resins. 111 The extracts, once eluted from the resins, were subjected to co-occurring phytoplankton and its growth was monitored. This method, while effective, does not accurately mimic natural exudation by the producing algae-naturally occurring plankton communities likely continually exude compounds instead of releasing high concentration "bursts." Furthermore, some allelochemicals might be induced as a response to competing organisms and would not be covered in extractions from monocultures. Modern approaches involve a coculture of the producing and receiving species with a barrier to prevent cell-cell contact. In this design, producing algae continually exude potentially allelopathic compounds for the duration of the experiment mimicking natural conditions. It also allows for the monitoring of induced effects that only manifest in the interaction situation. Whether the plankton are contained in a cage 107, 112 or in chambers separated by a mesh or a membrane (Fig. 8) , it is only the transfer of compounds that can illicit responses in competitor fitness.

Once the chemical basis for allelopathy is confirmed, the next step is the generation of extracts containing the excreted compounds. The exometabolome, or the collection of all compounds excreted by an organism, can be extracted via the resin method (as described above), by concentrating cell-free filtrate in vacuum, or via extraction through any number of solid-phase or solvent extraction techniques. 114 Extracts can then be subjected to bioassay-guided fractionation, an iterative cycle of separation, followed by intermittent bioassay testing to monitor activity. Induced processes can also be analyzed in a metabolomics investigation that involves profiling via analytical technologies such as mass spectrometry or nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy followed by multivariate statistical data evaluation techniques. In both cases, the goal is to identify the specific metabolites responsible for the observed modulation of competitor fitness. Metabolomics techniques are gaining popularity among chemical ecologists as more examples of waterborne cues are being identified through these techniques (for a full comparison of bioassayguided fractionation and metabolomics, see Poulin and Pohnert 115 ). Due to the aforementioned difficulties of working with waterborne cues, few allelopathic compounds have been identified from microalgae, yet significant data suggest their wider presence and community structuring effects. 104, [116] [117] [118] With technological advances in culturing techniques, analytical instrumentation, and statistical approaches being made, a more comprehensive understanding of the chemistry of microalgal allelopathy is on the horizon. One notable allelochemical class is karlotoxin (9) (Fig. 9 ) released by the dinoflagellate Karlodinium veneficum. 119 Using purified toxin and by coculturing K. veneficum with target species, Sheng and colleagues showed that karlotoxin affects the swimming characteristics of both predators and prey, including swimming speed and swimming trajectories. This makes karlotoxin (9) one of the first identified and best-characterized allelopathic compounds produced by phytoplankton.

Planktonic microalgae are rarely found in axenic conditions in nature. Many algal species form tight symbiotic associations with bacteria and as such, likely contain some mechanisms/machinery for transfer of chemistry. The first antibacterial agent derived from microalgae was proposed in 1944 as chlorellin. 120 The activity was detected in the green algae Chlorella vulgaris and Chlorella pyrenoidosa and suggested to act against co-occurring bacteria. First, bioassays were however only conducted against medically relevant bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus subtilis, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The approach of using medically relevant bacteria in bioassays has been pursued for many decades with the goal being the discovery of novel antibiotics that will fuel pharmaceutical needs. Similarly, the antifungal and antiviral properties of algal metabolites have mainly been determined for pharmaceutical applications 121 and food applications. 122 The ecological role of many of the identified compounds was rarely determined as the commercial value of identifying new compounds heavily outweighed the importance of understanding the biological relevance of the compounds to the producing organism. A well-described exception to this is the identification of superoxide as a mediator that negatively affects the common marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri. 123 Marshall and colleagues first investigated the concentration of superoxide produced by the raphidophyte Chattonella marina. In a chemoluminescence assay and discovered that superoxide production was density-dependent 124 . Superoxide produced by the addition of xanthine oxidase and xanthine substrate suppressed V. fischeri bioluminescence. The authors went on to show that superoxide, along with fatty acids such as eicosapentaenoic acid, has a toxic effect against damselfish. 123

Macroalgae are common members of most reef communities. Due to the relatively fast growth of macroalgae, they pose a threat to many slow-growing reef corals as corals and algae compete for space. This competition can be chemically mediated, and both corals and algae are known to produce inhibitory compounds. These compounds, unlike the waterborne cues released into the water column by microalgae, are excreted onto the surface of producing algae and as such, contact is generally required. The sequestration of the compounds on the algal surface allows for a unique set of analytical technologies to aid in the identification of the responsible chemistry. 125, 126 Corals have two main life stages, a planktonic larval stage and a sessile adult polyp. Macroalgae have developed specialized compounds to combat the larval stage and likely a unique set of compounds that damage the adult life stage. Paul and colleagues investigated the interaction between the brown algae Dictyota pulchella and Dictyota pinnatifida and the larval stage of the coral Porites astreoides. 127 To begin, extracts of both algal species were generated and applied to settlement tiles via an agar/carrageenan strip at concentrations between 3.7 and 3.9% wet weight. In addition to the tiles containing algal extracts, treatments included live algae attached to tiles, a fake aquarium plant attached to tiles to mimic algae but without compound production, blank tiles, and an agar/ carrageenan strip with ethanol only. All seven treatments were placed inside chambers that contained 100 coral larvae and chambers were placed in a seagrass bed in the field at 1.5-2 m depth. After 5 days, chambers were recovered and the percent of living larvae (both settled and free swimming) were determined. The extract of both algal species and live D. pinnatifida significantly reduced larval survival. Additionally, life D. pinnatifida and D. pulchella extract reduced larval settlement. To further test the allelopathic abilities of the macroalgae, tiles containing a single settled polyp were placed back into chambers and subjected to the same treatments as previously described. Physiological tests for photosystem health/efficiency were conducted to determine the nonlethal effect of algal metabolites while lethal effects were determined via the number of living polyps. The extracts of both species killed adult polyps but neither the extracts nor the live algae affected coral photophysiology. While the identities of the compounds responsible for the observed algal-derived allelopathy were not elucidated, the chemical basis for the response was described.

In another study aimed at finding the specific compounds responsible for allelopathy between eight algal species and three coral species, several macroalgal terpenes were identified as the causative agents. 128 Using a traditional bioassay-guided fractionation approach, the degraded sesquiterpenes 6-hydroxy-isololiolide (10) and isololiolide (11) from the red alga Galaxaura filamentosa and the acetylated diterpenes (E)-2-((3E,7E)-4,8,12-trimethyltrideca-3,7,11-trienyl)but-2-ene-1,4-diyl diacetate (12) and (1E,3E)-2-((3E,7E)-12-formyl-4,8-dimethyl-10-oxotrideca-3,7,12-trienyl)buta-1,3-diene-1,4-diyl diacetate (13) (Fig. 10) from Chlorodesmis fastigiata were found to be responsible for allelopathic activity against the corals Montipora digitata, Acropora millepora, and Pocillopora damicornis. 128

Macroalgae and microalgae, despite their different life histories (sessile attachment of macroalgae to a surface vs. biofilm-formers), do interact. While this interaction is not fully understood, it is known that some species of macroalgae produce compounds that inhibit the growth of microalgae. The widely cultivated seaweed Gracilaria lemaneiformis, for example, inhibits the growth of four microalgae: Scrippsiella trochoidea, Prorocentrum micans, Skeletonema costatum, and Dunaliella salina in laboratory as well as in mesocosm experiments. Yang and coworkers subjected laboratory cultures of the four microalgae to fresh thalli of macroalgae. All four species of microalgae grew to lower cell densities when compared to the same species not subjected to the macroalgae and for D. salina and S. costatum both died after 6 days. To test the effect in their natural environment, three mesocosm experiments were conducted in the same way as they were conducted in the laboratory but at a 1-, 50-, and 1000-L scale. In all mesocosm experiments the growth of microalgae was inhibited when macroalgae was added. Yang and coworkers highlight the possibility of cultivating macroalgae as a biological control against bloom-forming algae, although they suggest more studies are needed to support this strategy. 129 Several other studies suggest that the macroalgae Ulva spp. inhibit the growth of microalgae as well, indicating that the ability of macroalgae to structure microalgal communities might be more ubiquitous. [130] [131] [132]

Coralline algae are red algae with a calcified skeleton, characterized by a larger surface area to biomass ratio compared to most other macroalgae. These algae are thus highly vulnerable to biofouling. However, biofouling is uncommon on coralline algal surfaces, suggesting that they either release allelochemicals that dissuade planktonic bacteria from approaching the surface or that they excrete antibacterial compounds on their surfaces. While little research has investigated released allelochemicals, one study identified antibacterial compounds, peyssonoic acids A (14) and B (15) (Fig. 11) , that are present on the surface of coralline algae. 133 In this study, Lane and colleagues surveyed the antimicrobial activities of 69 collections of Fijian red macroalgae representing at least 43 unique species. All 69 collections exhibited some degree of antimicrobial activity against the bacterial pathogen Pseudoalteromonas bacteriolytica, and the fungal pathogen Lindra thalassiae suggesting that red algae are adept at defending themselves. They further investigated a single species, Peyssonnelia sp., which exhibited particularly potent antimicrobial activity. Through a series of bioassay-guided fractionation steps, two compounds, peyssonoic acid A and B were isolated and characterized. Peyssonoic acids A and B possess weak antibiotic activities with an IC of 800 and 380 mM against P. bacteriolytica, respectively. Due to the general lack of investigations in released chemistry from this class of algae, we believe that significant knowledge can be gained from the application of the methodologies described in the previous sections of this article, such as DESI-MS, and strongly invite an interested reader to review the following literature regarding the chemistry of coralline algae. 51, 134 The application of desorption electrospray ionization mass spectrometry could help to visualize where the allelopathic compounds are localized on the algal surfaces. This has exemplarily been shown by Lane and colleagues who used this MS-based approach to detect bromophycolide and callophycoic acid derivatives on the surface of the producing macroalga Callophycus serratus (Fig. 12) . 135 The compounds, known for antifungal activity against L. thalassiae, were found in distinct patches rather than uniformly distributed. Lane and coworkers hypothesized that the patchy distribution could be due to induction at sites of fungal challenge, or that patches could represent areas of surface wounding where compounds leaked into the surrounding environment. 135

As primary producers in aquatic ecosystems, grazers are the major predators of algae, which had to develop chemical defenses to maintain their population and sustain this stressor. 136 These defenses and the methodological approaches used to investigate them are the focus of the following subsections.

At the base of the oceanic food web and ranging in size from a few to several hundred micrometers, microalgae are susceptible to grazing. Especially copepods, small crustaceans found in almost all aquatic environments, are common grazers of microalgae. Some microalgae have developed chemical defenses against these grazers, and we refer to previous reviews for a comprehensive overview. 8 Here we want to highlight studies that, with an exceptional experimental soundness, clearly identify the role of defined toxins in grazing defense of microalgae such as the toxic dinoflagellate Karlodinium veneficum. 137 Waggett and colleagues subjected the copepod Acartia tonsa to six different mixed cultures consisting of various ratios of toxic and nontoxic K. veneficum. The clearance rate and ingestion rate of copepods were measured and it was found that while toxic K. veneficum did not induce mortality in copepod predators, both measured rates decreased significantly upon exposure to cultures with a higher proportion of toxic cells suggesting that K. veneficum toxins deter copepod grazing. 137 The toxins produced by K. veneficum, karlotoxins (9) (Fig. 9) , are also known to have an antigrazing effect against the heterotrophic dinoflagellate Oxyrrhis marina. 138 Adolf and colleagues showed that O. marina preferred nontoxic K. veneficum by subjecting the dinoflagellate to both toxic and nontoxic strains and measuring the relative prey abundance over 24 h. By also presenting O. marina with nontoxic K. veneficum with and without the addition of partially purified karlotoxin, they were able to determine that karlotoxin was the causative agent that led to decreased O. marina ingestion of prey. 138 Another species of Karlodinium, K. armiger, utilizes unknown chemistry to immobilize the copepod grazer, A. tonsa, and, as both a defensive measure and offensive measure, ingest A. tonsa through mixotrophic means. 139 Berge and colleagues showed that at natural bloom concentrations of K. armiger (greater than 1100 cells Â mL −1 ), copepods become immobilized within one hour and copepod survival decreased due to a switch in trophic role of the dinoflagellate from predator to prey. 139 Copepods have interestingly been found to release compounds into the water-column that induce toxin-production in prey microalgae. These compounds, called copepodamides (16) (17) (18) (19) (20) (21) (22) (23) (Fig. 13) , are released by Centropages typicus and members of the genus Calanus and induce up to a 20-fold increase in toxin-production in the dinoflagellate Alexandrium minutum. 140 Through a series of bioassay-guided fractionation steps, Selander and coworkers were able to identify eight different copepodamides and determine each compound's effective concentration for toxin doubling in Alexandrium cells. While not directly tested, it is hypothesized that the toxins act as feeding-deterrent against copepod grazers, as was shown for the toxins of another species of Alexandrium, A. fundyense, against the copepod Acartia hudsonica. 141

In terms of methodological approaches, the study of macroalgal antiherbivory utilizes many experimental techniques described in Sections 4.3-4.5 (Allelopathy of macroalgae) with the bioassay organisms changing from competitors to predators. Many studies on grazing defense chemistry focus on algae that inhabit the intertidal zone. The intertidal zone is characterized by intermittent periods of full submersion under water followed by periods of exposure to air. This zone is also home to many organisms that maintain special capabilities to resist desiccation and wide ranges in temperature, salinity, and UV exposure which can significantly change between high and low tide. Herbivore grazers, including the snail Littorina littorea, have such survival strategies. Many macroalgae from all lineages have developed chemical defense mechanisms to counter the herbivore pressure. These range from the production of concentrated sulfuric acid to the release of most elaborate chemical defenses as reviewed in. 8 Early examples include the brown algae Fucus vesiculosus and Ascophyllum nodosum that produce phloroglucinol polymers of a wide molecular weight range that defend against L. littorea. 142 Using standard bioassay-guided fractionation and a series of now-outdated analytical techniques, Geiselman and McConnell were able to identify the structure of the defense compounds almost 40 years ago. Feeding experiments in which L. littorea were fed commercially available analogues as well as feed containing algal extracts supported the antiherbivory capabilities of these compounds. 142 Similar feeding or palatability studies are still conducted, illustrating the power of this direct approach. [143] [144] [145]

A helpful classification within chemical defenses to understand the ecology of species is that of inducible vs. activated vs. constitutive defenses. Inducible defenses are those that are not continuously produced but are triggered by chemical signals released by the herbivores. These so-called elicitors trigger a defense response that is controlled by algal hormones. Activated defense requires the enzymatic processing of stored metabolites to arm otherwise less active storage metabolites. Activated defenses are triggered by wounding of organisms or disruption of cells via physical trauma. Constitutive defenses are compounds that are stored within an organism in their active form. Significant debate surrounds the cost/benefit of inducible vs. activated vs. constitutive defenses. 146, 147 Until the 1990s, the prevalence of constitutive defenses was assumed for algae while the concepts of induced defenses were being discovered in higher plants. 148 Then two studies shed light on the ability to trigger and induce algal defenses. [149] [150] [151] For example, despite not identifying the responsible compounds, Goodman and Hay showed that three freshwater red algae Batrachospermum helminthosum, Kumanoa holtonii, and Tuomeya americana utilized inducible defenses against the native crayfish, Cambarus latimanus, and the nonendemic crayfish, Procambarus clarkii. 143 When the palatability of macroalgae with activated defenses (freeze-thaw events were used to lyse cells and allow for enzymatic reactions) was compared to that of the same algae that were not activated (freeze-thaw in methanol to inactivate enzymes and prevent arming of chemical defenses), it was found that the activation process increases the chemical defense against herbivores. 143 In another study, it was found that the brown algae Fucus vesiculosus produces an antiherbivory compound(s) upon exposure to amphipod attacks while other tested algae, Dictyopteris membranacea, Gelidium sesquipedale, and Sphaerococcus coronopifolius, did not have inducible defenses. 144 Yun and coauthors tested the palatability of live macroalgae and lipophilic extracts of macroalgae exposed or not to the amphipod grazers Gammarus insensibilis, Gamarella fucicola, and Cymadusa filosa for 14 days. Live algae and lipophilic extracts of F. vesiculosus exposed to grazers were significantly less palatable in multichoice feeding assays, supporting the hypothesis that this alga must utilize an inducible defense. 144 While we know many of the elicitors in higher plant defenses, we are just starting to understand the regulation of induced defenses in algae and believe that this exciting field will grow significantly in the coming years.
body_text.section: Fig. 13 Structures of copepodamides A to H (16-23).

body_text.text: Some microbes can colonize submerged or wet surfaces through adhesion and thereby initiate the formation of a biofilm. 152, 153 A major driving force for bacteria that usually colonize first is the presence of adsorbed molecules including proteins, polysaccharides, and lipids, acting as a microbe-attracting conditioning film. 154, 155 Microbial excretion of extracellular polymeric substances (EPS), mainly consisting of proteins and lipids, modifies the substrate that allows for further colonization of unicellular species from various kingdoms, including bacteria, cyanobacteria, and algae. The role of EPS is thereby highly diverse, giving the biofilm an adhesive microenvironment that protects the cells inside from rapid environmental changes, like sudden dehydration (in the littoral zone), pH, and temperature. The EPS can protect from external toxins but also serve as a mean to accumulate toxins produced by a biofilm inhabitant. 152, 156, 157 Besides the initial biofilm-forming species, coexisting species in the biofilm can produce EPS as well and can form symbiotic relationships within the community. In aquatic environments, matured biofilms furthermore allow for the settlement of multicellular eukaryotes, like macroalgae, mussels, and barnacles, which is known as the process of macrofouling. 152, 158 In this section recent discoveries of (algal) biofilm-algae interaction shall be highlighted. The focus is set on microalgal biofilms and how they interact with their biological environment.

The production of EPS that form the protective scaffold of biofilms is the characteristic property that allows microorganisms to switch from a planktonic state to a sessile lifestyle. As aforementioned, EPS comprise a variety of substance classes, such as charged and uncharged polysaccharides, proteins, that include mainly protein-, polysaccharide-, lipid-degrading enzymes, humic substances, and extracellular DNA. An excellent overview of the components of EPS and their individual functions was given by Flemming and Wingender. 157 Benthic pennate diatoms excrete EPS through an elongated slit in the frustule, known as raphe to move in a gliding manner on the surface. Video recording and modeling of the movement revealed that the biofilm-forming marine benthic diatom Seminavis robusta uses its mobility for foraging-behavior, following gradients of the essential nutrient silicate. 159 During nutrients limitation, the diatoms can prioritize and direct their movement to silicate or the sex pheromone diproline, a behavior explaining the often observed patchy species distribution in biofilms. 23 Algal biofilm formation is under the influence of nutrients, like nitrogen, phosphorus, or sulfur, but recent studies also show that associated bacteria influence the growth and distribution of algae. 160 Cultivating the freshwater diatom Cymbella microcephala with co-occurring isolated bacterial strains changed drastically the excretion pattern of soluble and bound polysaccharides that are associated to the cell or the substratum depending on the cocultivated bacterial strain. In presence of the Bacteroidetes strain 32, the abundance of soluble polysaccharides decreased, while an increase of bound EPS was observed. The addition of autoclaved spent medium of this strain also induced encapsulation of the diatom, indicating the presence of an unknown heat stable mediator produced by the bacterium. 161 Encapsulation was also observed in cocultures of the freshwater diatom Achnanthidium minutissimum in mixed-fermentation cultures containing the Bacteroidetes strain, or pure monocultures spiked with the spent bacterial medium. 162 Scanning electron microscopy images revealed that the capsules mediate bacterial attachment, whereby the authors argued that the capsule could act as a nutrient pool to attract heterotrophic bacteria that may provide vitamins and mineralize EPS. 163 Furthermore, coculture experiments of isolated freshwater diatoms and the marine diatom Phaeodactylum tricornutum demonstrated that the presence of bacteria Escherichia coli was essential for proteins excretion. The expression of coculture dependent proteins and their quantification was conducted with denaturing gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE). Peptide mapping by mass spectrometry from cocultivated P. tricornutum and Escherichia coli revealed that the secreted proteins were involved in signaling, sugars uptake, amino acids modification, and proteins aggregation in diatoms and bacteria. 164 The a-proteobacterium Roseovarius strain 217 (R217) induced a morphotypic transition in the diatom from planktonic, fusiform (spindle-shaped) cells to benthic, oval cells, when grown in coculture with P. tricornutum. Diatoms supplemented with sterile filtered bacterial supernatant of R217 showed the same effect. Not only the morphology of the cells was affected, but also the overall growth of the diatom biofilm was increased and aggregation of cells was pronounced compared to pure monocultures. 165 Microalgal EPS may have species dependent beneficial or detrimental effects on the associated bacteria. 166 EPS that were extracted from axenic Navicula phyllepa, a diatom found in intertidal mudflat biofilms were administered to the different bacteria Flavobacterium sp. II2003, Roseobacter sp. IV3009, and Shewanella sp. IV3014 and biofilm development was monitored. The biofilm thickness of Flavobacterium sp. was significantly decreased, while the biofilm thickness of Roseobacter sp. and Shewanella sp. was not affected. Notably, the EPS showed only antibiofilm activity and no antibacterial properties. To identify the active fraction in the diatom EPS, several nucleases, proteases, a lipase, and sodium periodate were applied on the EPS, which were then assessed in a functional bioassay. The EPS that were treated with NaIO 4, an agent that oxidizes mostly carbohydrates, had no effect on the biofilm formation, indicating that the carbohydrates were potentially the most active fraction of the algal EPS. 166
body_text.section: The Making of an Algal Biofilm

body_text.text: The dense biofilms are also environments where allelopathy manifests on small and larger scales. 167, 168 Since biofilms are not entirely isolated from the free water-column, many allelochemicals can be exchanged and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) can play a major role in algal biofilm interactions. 169, 170 The roles of released allelochemicals range from algal defense compounds, foraging kairomones that attract grazers, to allelopathic compounds that are beneficial for the sender organism. A well-structured overview of the hitherto identified allelopathy between benthic microalgae was prepared by Allen et al., which did not cover crosskingdom interactions. 168 In the present subsection, we cover the chemical interactions between biofilm-forming microalgae, bacteria, and other algae, selecting the most relevant examples of allelochemicals involved in foraging-behavior (kairomones) and with antifeeding properties (allomones). To ease the complex interactions, we distinguished the metabolites from algal biofilms according to their chemical classes.
body_text.section: Selected Chemical Mediators From Benthic Algae

body_text.text: Oxylipins from diatoms are associated with their chemical defense and often linked to the dynamic development of microalgal biofilms. [171] [172] [173] Oxylipins can be released upon cell wounding or disruption, but can also be excreted by intact diatom cells. 174 One of the most investigated oxylipin is decadienal (24) (Fig. 14) , which is able to inhibit cell growth of some microalgae species. 175 When tested on biofilm-forming freshwater diatoms, decadienal influenced the algal motility, adhesion and aggregation behavior impacting the biofilm formation. Leflaive et al. linked the adhesion-preventive activity of decadienal to an induced intracellular nitric oxide (NO) accumulation revealed by a fluorescent molecular probe. Applying the NO donor sodium nitroprusside to the cells also prevented adhesion to the substratum. These results are in accordance with an earlier study that showed that decadienal could induce NO production in the marine diatom P. tricornutum and thereby decreased the cell adhesion to the substratum. 176 Strikingly, decadienal affected only planktonic algal forms and not benthic diatoms cells already attached to a substratum. The advanced biofilm might contain cross-linked EPS protecting the attached cells from the harmful effect of decadienal. In another study, biofilm-forming diatoms that produced decadienal prevented the adhesion of other competing diatom cells. 172 An external application of decadienal to a coculture of two biofilm-forming diatom species significantly influenced the species proportions. 172 The adhesion-preventive activity of decadienal at sublethal concentrations was tested against freshwater benthic diatoms, which greatly varied in-between genera. 173 In accordance, fluorescence quenching analyses showed that decadienal had a reversible influence on the physiological state of the algae by negatively affecting the photosystem II. These results indicate that biofilmforming algae, which produce decadienal or compounds with similar activities, are able to modulate the species composition of their environment.
body_text.section: Selected Chemical Mediators From Benthic Algae

body_text.text: Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) produced by filamentous green algae were identified as allelopathic agents using bioassayguided fractionation. 177, 178 The C 18 fatty acids such as linoleic acid (25) and a-linolenic acid showed strong growth-inhibiting activities at a concentration range from 0.25 to 14.5 mg Â mL −1 against other green algae, diatoms, and cyanobacteria. 177 The mode of action of these free fatty acids against algae and cyanobacteria primarily involved alteration of the plasma membrane permeability. As a secondary effect, dissociation of phycobilins from thylakoids was observed while the stressed cell collapsed under the lytic effect. 179 Since the free fatty acids are not only involved in allelopathy but also serve in intracellular functions, the regulation of the PUFAs production and release by the algae is a compelling system to study the two most debated plant defense models, namely the growth-differentiation balance hypothesis (GDBH) and the optimal defense theory (ODT). GDBH predicts that there is a trade-off between growth and the allocation of resources (e.g. defense mechanisms) while ODT foresees that algae will defend themselves in an appropriate relation to the faced risks. 180 Allen et al. therefore investigated how several biotic and abiotic parameters, including growth phase and nutrient limitation, influenced the production and release of the PUFAs by the benthic filamentous green alga Uronema confervicolum. 181 The intra-and extracellular contents of the allelopathic linoleic acid (25) and a-linolenic acid were monitored in late-exponentially grown algal cultures, but nor the ODT or the GDBH models could explain the findings entirely. While increasing light conditions led to a higher production of the analyzed PUFAs (pro-GDBH), a negative feedback mechanism for PUFAs production was observed (pro-ODT), calling for the evaluation of new defense models. 181 In another study, a cryptic link between the habitat and the chemical properties of the involved allelopathic compounds was found by Chiang et al. 178 The authors argued that the linoleic acid and a-linolenic acid producing green alga Botryococcus braunii were averaging its slightly alkaline freshwater environment (Liyu Lake, Taiwan) to keep the PUFAs in their deprotonated state when released. 178 During the study of the bioactivity of biofilm-forming diatoms P. tricornutum, the free fatty acids and the PUFAs were found highly active against a broad spectrum range of bacteria, including the strains of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). 182, 183 Desbois et al. showed that the PUFA-producing marine diatom P. tricornutum had greater antibacterial properties when it occurred in its pelagic, fusiform shape, compared to the benthic oval lifestyle. 184 In the pelagic state, P. tricornutum produced much greater amounts of the free fatty acids eicosapentaenoic acid, hexadecatrienoic acid, and palmitoleic acid that were related to the antibacterial activity of the diatom. 184 The exact mechanism of action of free fatty acids against bacteria is still under investigation, but due to the amphiphilic character of fatty acids and the high concentration detected, detergent effects induced cell death by membrane disruption. 183, 185 The low concentration of free fatty acids was suggested as the reason for cell death, as the cell wall permeability was increased as a result. 185 Despite the knowledge that has been gained about the roles of volatile polyunsaturated aldehydes (PUAs) in the environment of microalgae, their role as repellent compounds against grazers is up to now still under investigations. Several studies focus on the role of PUAs in grazing behavior, whereby only copepods as the main class of grazers have been considered. [186] [187] [188] [189] Nevertheless, the release of PUAs and other lipoxygenase (LOX) products is not only advantageous for the producing benthic microalgae. Some gastropod herbivores are able to smell the volatile substances that have been released from damaged benthic microalgae and follow the trace to graze on them. 190, 191 An analysis of the bouquet from the biofilm mat of benthic freshwater green alga Ultrothrix fimbriata that has been mechanically damaged revealed the presence of LOX products such as the C 5 products 1-pentene-3-one, 1-pentene-3-ol, and the C 7 aldehydes 2E,4(E/Z)-heptadienal (26) . In a choice-assay, the herbivorous snail Radix ovata was exposed to either a mixture of the C 5 and C 7 products or only the single product, respectively. 191 The compound mixture elicited a foragingbehavior toward the source in the snail. Jüttner et al. showed in systematic bioassays that the release of LOX products by epiphytic marine diatom Cocconeis scutellum var. parva affect a whole variety of habitat-connected animals like decapods, gastropods, amphiand isopods, polychaetes, and fish. The animals were either repelled, or attracted toward the VOCs bouquet of C. scutellum parva in a dose-dependent manner, testifying of the complexity of interactions that arises from just one emitted compound class. 192 To assess if herbivorous snails are also able select certain food sources by their quality, the common freshwater pond snail Lymnaea stagnalis was exposed in a choice-assay to VOCs bouquets of the benthic freshwater algae U. fimbriata that has been cultivated either under phosphate and nitrate depletion (low-quality food) or nutrient-saturated conditions (high-quality food). The pond snail clearly preferred the VOCs bouquet of the high-quality food source over the low-quality food source, indicating significant changes in the VOCs composition of the algae. Indeed, a comparison of the bouquets of U. fimbriata under phosphate-limiting, nitrogen-limiting, and nutrient-saturated conditions showed a qualitative shift in the VOCs compositions, but also higher yields of total VOCs obtained under nutrient-saturated conditions. Despite the quantitative and qualitative differences of the detected VOCs, the authors suggested that the qualitative changes in the composition (presence/absence of certain volatiles) were definitively influencing the snail's foraging-behavior. 193 Benthic microalgae are known to produce many feeding-deterrent compounds and mainly VOCs that support the biofilm maintenance over time.
body_text.section: Selected Chemical Mediators From Benthic Algae

body_text.text: Nevertheless, besides VOCs, other metabolites from the algal biofilm can act as feeding-deterrent against grazers. It is the case of the pigment-derived group of apo-fucoxanthinoids, which was identified from Phaeodactylum tricornutum through a bioassay-guided fractionation and which inhibited grazing by copepods Tigriopus californicus. 194 These compounds are derived from the major diatom pigment fucoxanthin and are similar to the so-called grasshopper ketone that also acts as a feeding-deterrent in the grasshopper Romalea microptera against predators. 195 Bioactive polyphenols have been studied for several decades in macroalgae defense and were recently recognized to play a role in algal biofilm interactions as well. [196] [197] [198] The first polyphenol characterized in benthic algal biofilms is marennine, which is produced by a recently discovered new genus of marine diatoms, Haslea. These algae may live in mutualistic interaction with oysters and were detected historically in aquaculture farms due to their deep blue coloration. 199 The responsible pigment is marennine, a molecule with till now unknown structure, which exhibits a reversible bathochromic shift under changing pH conditions, giving the diatom a green or blue color according to alkaline or acidic conditions. 199 The compound was recently characterized for its antibacterial and antiviral properties along with its allelopathic activity, revealed when tested against coexisting microalgae. 200, 201 Two different forms of marennine exist, namely intra-(IMn) and the released extracellular marennine (EMn), which were characterized by Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) and Raman spectroscopy. 199 Both IMn and EMn showed similar activities against tested microalgae, reducing their growth rate significantly. Since marennine is a pigment, the authors tested if the mode of action of marennine is due to chemical mediation or due to its ability to act as a light filter. To test whether that marennine acts only as an optical filter, they placed marennine solutions of different concentrations in-between cultures and the light-source. As the concentration of marennine was increased, the growth rates of the algae were negatively affected. The addition of marennine to the cultures showed a clear dose-dependent growth inhibition, confirming both hypotheses. 200 The full characterization of IMn and EMn is still under investigation, though partial structure analysis by NMR confirmed that marennine has both polyphenolic and glycosidic elements, while its size was estimated to be around 10 kDa. 199 Several more species of Haslea ostrearia-like diatoms have been recently discovered, that also exhibit the presence of marennine-like blue pigments, indicating that the production of this infochemical may be conserved within the diatom genus Haslea. 202 The diversity of halogenated compounds in algae is exceptional. A huge proportion of those belong to the class of volatile organic halocarbons (VOX) that usually contain less than five carbons. For macroalgae, ecologically relevant bioactivities of VOXs could be determined, including antigrazing, anticolonizing, and antimicrobial activities. 203 Nevertheless, microalgae are important producers of VOX as well, but still only few studies could reveal the possible role of VOX in the habitat. 204, 205 Nitzschia cf. pellucida, a VOX producing benthic marine diatom exhibits strong allelopathic effects in coculture with the naturally competing microalgae species Entomoneis paludosa, Cylindrotheca closterium, and Navicula arenaria. 205 The cocultivated microalgae were killed after 24 h exposure to N. cf. pellucida, whereby all tested microalgae suffered from loss of pigmentation and shriveling of the chloroplasts. Headspace analysis of the bouquet of N. cf. pellucida showed the presence of several methylhalogens, di-and trihalomethanes, halogenated acetaldehyde species, but also the highly toxic cyanogen bromide (BrCN). Vanelslander et al. could show in vitro that from all produced VOX only BrCN could kill the cocultivated microalga E. paludosa in a dose-dependent manner.
