Changing the levels of Br − :I − in the medium toward high I − concentrations resulted in the formation of ICN, indicating the presence of halogen oxidizing enzymes. The presence of these H 2 O 2 -dependent haloperoxidases (HPO) was confirmed with a colorimetric assay. The authors observed that the presence of BrCN in the culture medium was not constant over time, with the highest concentration observed between 2 and 4 h after onset of light. Moreover, the production was light-dependent ( Fig. 15) . Keeping the diatom cells under conditions of prolonged darkness completely abolished BrCN production. The authors hypothesized that N. cf. pellucida takes advantage of the Mehler reaction that occurs in chloroplasts after onset of light, leading to temporal increased H 2 O 2 amounts, consecutively used in a HPO-dependent reaction to oxidize Br − . 205 Strikingly, BrCN itself did not exhibit antibacterial properties at the produced concentrations, but HPOs instead could be linked to a quorum quenching activity. 204 Quorum quenching thereby describes mechanisms to inactivate quorum sensing (QS), usually achieved through enzymatic degradation of QS-molecules, QS-inhibitors, and QS-molecule antagonists. 206 Syrpas et al. used two bacterial reporter strains to test how the HPOs of N. cf. pellucida interfere with the widely common QS-molecule class of acylhomoserine lactones (AHLs). 204 Therefore, two representative AHLs were compared; N-hexanoyl homoserine lactone (HHL) and N-3-oxohexanoyl homoserine lactone (OHHL) that in contrast contains a b-keto moiety (Scheme 1). The AHLs were incubated with N. cf. pellucida and subsequently tested on the bacterial reporter strains. The AHL-synthase deficient mutant strain of Chromobacterium violaceum (CV026) produces in presence of AHLs the purple pigment violacein. The pigment production could only be impaired by the treated OHHL, while HHL always remained active. The authors concluded that the presence of a b-keto moiety in AHLs was necessary to be affected by the diatom HPO. To analyze how the b-keto-AHLs were affected by the HPOs, the OHHL spiked cultures were extracted over time and the degradation products were analyzed with HPLC-MS (Scheme 1). A degradation pathway was already suggested, 207 which was confirmed by Syrpas et al. with the double bromination of the a-position of (27) under generation of water. The reaction finally results in the cleavage of the halogenated N-acyl-side chain, producing (30) and (31) . 204 Testing a variety of synthetic analogues to (27, 28, 29) on Escherichia coli JB523 that expresses the green fluorescent protein in presence of AHLs revealed that (29) and (31) act as agonists and that (32) has no activity.
body_text.section: Selected Chemical Mediators From Benthic Algae

body_text.text: Most of the ecological functions of algal metabolites that were elucidated during the past years have only been recognized thanks to interdisciplinary approaches. As seen with the examples in this article, the interactions of any organism with algae can have short lifespans (few hours) or take up to months to establish and unfold. Single organisms can have multiple functions dependent on the context, as shown for bacteria that can shift from mutualistic to parasitic interaction with algae. 93 As algal infochemicals are often produced with short lifespans at very low concentration in the diffuse aqueous substrata, more efforts on developing highly sensitive analytics and imaging are expected to detect the chemical mediators in the field. Achievements using novel approaches such as in silico modeling, 70 mixed fermentations and outdoor experimental systems (mesocosms) will help to better understand the complexity of algal communities in the environment.

FIGREF0.text: The life cycle of Seminavis robusta. The diatoms reproduce by successive mitosis, which induces a decrease in cell size. Upon reaching the Sexual Size Threshold, the mating cell types (MT -) and (MT+) produce sex-inducing pheromones (SIP) which induce the release of the attraction pheromone diproline by (MT -). The partner mating type (MT+) may produce a specific diproline receptor and this signaling leads to the mate finding and pairing to form a zygote during gametogenesis. The initial cell size is restored by elongation of the auxospores. This figure is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. From Moeys, S.; Frenkel, J.; Lembke, C.; Gillard, J. T. F.; Devos, V.; Van den Berge, K.; Bouillon, B.; Huysman, M. J. J.; De Decker, S.; Scharf, J.; Bones, A.; Brembu, T.; Winge, P.; Sabbe, K.; Vuylsteke, M.; Clement, L.; De Veylder, L.; Pohnert, G.; Vyverman, W., A Sex-Inducing Pheromone Triggers Cell Cycle Arrest and Mate Attraction in the Diatom Seminavis robusta. Sci. Rep. 2016, 6, 19252.

FIGREF1.text: Tripartite community of green macroalgae Ulva mutabilis and interactions with associated bacteria Roseobacter sp. and Cytophaga sp. which excrete morphogenetic substances involved in the growth and morphogenesis of the algal host. The two algal morphotypes are represented in captions A and B (scale bars equal to 1 mm). This work is under Creative Commons Attribution License (CC BY) from Wichard, T., Exploring Bacteria-Induced Growth and Morphogenesis in the Green Macroalga order Ulvales (Chlorophyta). Front. Plant Sci. 2015, 6(86).

FIGREF3.text: Scheme of the life stages of aquatic zoosporic parasites of phytoplankton. The life cycle of parasites of algae comprises of two phases, a free-living form, the zoospore, that swims in the surrounding environment and is attracted by a susceptible host, and a host-associated form (the trophont) that feeds upon the infected algae. After successful mitotic divisions, the parasite either enters a resting stage or transforms into the sporocyst to produce flagellated spores, which are released to start a new infection cycle.From Jephcott, T. G.; Alves-de-Souza, C.; Gleason, F. H.; van Ogtrop, F. F.; Sime-Ngando, T.; Karpov, S. A.; Guillou, L., Ecological Impacts of Parasitic Chytrids, Syndiniales and Perkinsids on Populations of Marine Photosynthetic Dinoflagellates. Fungal Ecol. 2016, 19, 47-58.

FIGREF4.text: Structures of growth promoter and antibiotics(2,3) and roseobacticides(4), which are produced by bacteria P. gallaeciensis from the Roseobacter clade, and p-coumaric acid (5) produced by the alga E. huxleyi.

FIGREF5.text: Structures of pyrenocine A (6), B (7), and pyrenochaetic acid C (8) with broad range activities against protistan pathogens of macroalgae.

FIGREF6.text: Noncontact dual cultivation apparatus to grow organisms without direct contact but ensuring the exchange of metabolites through medium diffusion. (A) Disassembled setup displaying all necessary parts and (B) assembled coculture device. A 0.22-mm membrane separates both chambers that can each be filled with up to 500 mL medium. Scale bars equal to 10 cm in both panels. From Paul, C.; Mausz, M. A.; Pohnert, G., A Co-Culturing/Metabolomics Approach to Investigate Chemically Mediated Interactions of Planktonic Organisms Reveals Influence of Bacteria on Diatom Metabolism. Metabolomics 2013, 9(2), 349-359.

R.; Prudhomme, J.; Le Roch, K.; Hay, M. E.; Aalbersberg, W.; Kubanek, J., Ecological Leads for Natural Product Discovery: Novel Sesquiterpene Hydroquinones From the Red Macroalga Peyssonnelia sp. Tetrahedron 2010, 66(2), 455-461.

FIGREF10.text: Structures and negative-ion desorption electrospray ionization (DESI) mass spectra of bromophycolides. (A) Mass spectra of bromophycolides A and B deposited on synthetic substrates. Ion clusters centered around m/z 665 and 701 correspond to [bromophycolide A/B − H] − and [bromophycolide A/B + Cl] − , respectively. (B) DESI mass spectra of the C. serratus surface, showing that bromophycolides occur on algal surfaces only in association with light-colored patches. Ion clusters centered at 583 and 619 represent [bromophycolide E − H] − and [bromophycolide E + Cl] − , respectively. (C) DESI-MS image (200 mm resolution) of bromophycolide A/B chloride adduct ion m/z 701 on C. serratus surface, indicating that bromophycolide "hot spots" correspond to pale patches. (D) Representative mass spectrum from patch-free algal surface before and after mechanical damage. With permission from Lane et al. Lane, A. L.; Nyadong, L.; Galhena, A. S.; Shearer, T. L.; Stout, E. P.; Parry, R. M.; Kwasnik, M.; Wang, M. D.; Hay, M. E.; Fernandez, F. M., Desorption Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry Reveals Surface-Mediated Antifungal Chemical Defense of a Tropical Seaweed. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 2009, 106(18), 7314-7319, copyright (2009) National Academy of Sciences.

FIGREF12.text: Time-and light-dependent production of BrCN in Nitzschia cf. pellucida cultures over 1 day. The BrCN concentration (black line) and the effect of N. cf. pellucida cell-free spent medium harvested at different time points on competitor E. paludosa cells (gray line) are induced both few hours after sunrise. Copyright (2012) National Academy of Sciences. From Vanelslander, B.; Paul, C.; Grueneberg, J.; Prince, E. K.; Gillard, J.; Sabbe, K.; Pohnert, G.; Vyverman, W., Daily Bbursts of Bbiogenic Ccyanogen Bbromide (BrCN) Control Biofilm Formation Around a Marine Benthic Diatom. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 2012, 109(7), 2412-2417.
